text.p: NARODNA OBRODA - President Michal Kovac said exclusion of Slovakia from the first wave of NATO enlargement can further damage the country's credibility.
- Some 18,000 inhabitans of the western Slovak spa Piestany had to be evacuated from their homes due to high water on the river Vah. Water levels are reported to be gradually falling.

- The government is preparing a series of measures to help boost the export actvities of small and medium-sized companies. The new measures should include small loans covering export- production related costs.
- The Finance Ministry said it was considering allowing local companies and citizens to buy special issues of state securities to allocate new sources for covering state budget deficit.

- Prime Minister Vladimir Meciar said French electronic equipment producer Bull would create a joint-venture with ZVT a.s., an electronics firm based in the central Slovak town Banska Bystrica. The joint-venture should start producing computers next October.

- President Kovac has returned a law banning privatisation of the official Slovak Television's second channel to parliament at the request of the government. The President must return any law to parliament for reassesment if asked by cabinet to do so.
SME - Kovac said Meciar had shown little effort to get Slovakia into NATO in the first enlargement wave.
- Regulation of wages as proposed by the government will not solve fundamental economic problems, economists said.
- The government has named Nomura International Plc the lead manager of a $250 Eurobond issue planned later this year.

PRAVDA - Slovak banks have begun informing police of suspicious financial transactions. According to a new law, banks must report suspicious operations including withdrawals or deposits of cash over 500,000 crowns.
HOSPODARSKE NOVINY - Recent flooding in Slovakia is expected to significantly negatively affect this year's grain harvest.
